By Steve J. LarsenFOREWORD
“Mr. Larsen, you have no recurring revenue and
YOU are the business.”
When I was only three years into my business,
I had sold around $8,000,000 of my own offers
online, and a real business valuation service
was pouring over financials and market data
to see how much money my little empire was
actually worth. After a several week waiting
game, the answer struck my core with a nasty
disgust I’ll never forget. Ready?
My business was worth barely $500k.
“What?! WHY!? Look at the sales!! Look at the
audience! How can a business around $8 million
in sales be worth only $500k?!” I was enraged.
But the answer was the very first line above,
which was one of the biggest business gut
punches I’ve ever experienced. “Mr. Larsen,
you have no recurring revenue and YOU are the
business.”
I don’t think anyone would say millions in sales is
a failure, but I also clearly saw how devastating it
is to build a business with YOU as the continuity,
rather than build a business with its own
continuity. Make sense? I’d been doing it wrong. I
didn’t have a business; I had a promotion.What was even more painful was knowing that
I had a little nagging voice in my head that
kept saying, “go build continuity and build up
recurring revenue” but I never did it.
So how could I have built it all wrong then?
Turns out I missed a few of the more subtle
parts of the Value Ladder, which is easy to do.
Let me explain.
The first time I heard Russell Brunson say
“Value Ladder” was about 10 years ago, and
it changed my entrepreneurial life. I felt like
I suddenly had the language to describe
the marketing plans in my head. It changed
everything for me. At the time, I was getting
a marketing degree, which never delivered
as much marketing clarity in my classes as
the Value Ladder did. The concept is now an
industry standard of how we communicate
marketing.
The Value Ladder concept has become such
a powerful and universal way to express
entrepreneur and marketing ideas that even
those who try to compete with Russell online
use his own model to attempt to poorly
outwit him.What I really missed in those earlier years can
be shown in how most people draw a Value
Ladder. If you haven’t seen one before, it looks
like three or four stair steps and visually shows
how you’ll ascend your customers. The real
problem is that’s where people usually stop
drawing. However, it’s not complete. That’s not
the Value Ladder unless the other part is there.
What most people don’t draw is the part in the
red box. It’s missed frequently, and the three
little arrows symbolize the part I was missing
too: continuity.
Somewhere along the line, our internet
marketing industry kind of forgot about those
little “continuity arrows” and instead just drew more rungs on the ladder. We all have 1,000
ideas each day, so it’s easy to start shifting
away from a completed Value Ladder and
instead just add infinite steps so your ideas
have a place to live. Their Value Ladders kind
of end up looking like the opening scene in Ace
Ventura Pet Detective, where he’s sending a
slinky down hundreds of steps.
No judgment. Been there, done that. But take a
moment to turn up the “real talk” dial and lean
in a bit, because NOT creating and focusing on
continuity in my early business life is the single
greatest business regret I have. No contest.
How I wish I had done things differently…
6 7
That’s why the Linchpin is so powerful and
sorely needed.
The Linchpin is the difference between having
an actual business and having just one-off sales
streaks. It guides the entrepreneur’s visionary
thoughts into a productive revenue model and
ensures that all ideas anchor back to solving
real business needs. Without that, it’s easy to
start running your business based on the idea-
of-the-day. I’ve found that the Linchpin really
helps solve any tensions between the visionary
entrepreneurs and the rest of their teams too,
because now everyone can point back to the
same drawn vision.
I hope that as you read this book you see all
the other business questions the Linchpin also
solves. There’s a lot.
For example, every business, whether you’re
a Fortune 500 or a living room start-up, is
constantly hungry for two things: daily cash flow
and daily lead flow. The Linchpin solves both.
The game is about increasing your control over
cash flow and lead flow as much as possible.
And although the big cash days are nice, it’s
really about cash flow. That’s what I was
missing in my business.
It’s ironic how few internet entrepreneurs
actually have continuity, considering that
the dream of a laptop beach lifestyle is the
reason that got many of us started. However,
it’s very hard to grow a healthy business
without knowing how much money is coming
in tomorrow. Truly, cash flow is king.
If you’re thinking, “Well I just need leads, Steve!”
Ok, but even if the dreamiest of customers is
buying from you today, do you know you will
attract a new lead tomorrow, in a process that
doesn’t require you? The Linchpin solves both
of your cash flow and lead flow problems.
I also found that focusing on continuity
allows entrepreneurs to dramatically increase
customer experience. It was a surprising
benefit that I saw for myself. I no longer had to constantly come up with new offers PLUS
all the marketing AND the delivery. Now, I
could use my energy to actually grow the same
business, instead of giving birth to a new one.
I had both cash flow and mental space to
make continuous improvements to my core
continuity.
I’ve found a lot of business simplicity in
using the Linchpin too. Most know my crazy
beginning, that I went through 34 product
failures before one actually worked. On the
35th attempt, I was so excited it finally worked
that I think I got a little addicted, and over the
next four years I created and released over
55 different offers of my own. I very much
get having a lot of product ideas, but the
entrepreneurial angels sang on the day that I
deleted 52 of them. Why?
I bring this up only because I’ve seen
thousands of Value Ladders representing
hundreds of markets, and as you read this
book, it’s going to feel easy to get more
ideas than the Linchpin model holds. GOOD!
Let what you’re about to read force you to
keep, combine, or kill your offer ideas. It’s
about creating better offers, not necessarily
more offers.
Finally, remember, just because it’s a good idea
doesn’t mean you should do it (I’m not one to
talk there), but let the Linchpin guide the offers
you choose to build so they’re in one ascending
theme. The Linchpin is about creating one
theme that your offers all attach to. For
example, it’s very common for an entrepreneur
to hand me their Value Ladder plans to critique
only for me to hand it back and point out, “This
isn’t a Value Ladder. This is three individual
businesses that are all referring traffic to each
other. A Value Ladder is one business theme
with three offers all leading to continuity.” The
Linchpin solves this by helping the entrepreneur
focus on creating one strong theme throughout
the product line of a company, rather than lots
of unrelated offers.
Read this book in its entirety. Be a thorough
student. I haven’t read a lot of guru’s books because I study Russell. I’ve been in his office
many times and watched as his gift unfolds
massive amounts of information, and then
pops out simplicity with a stick figure doodle.
Then a whole market will shift.
Like many entrepreneurs, I see the work we
do to help others as near-sacred. I’ve known
Russell Brunson personally for 8 years. His
work ethic and drive is unparalleled. His
mission is not about riches. He already did that.
A lot and then more. He shows up over and
over because he likes to solve entrepreneur
problems at a large scale, and this book is no
different.
Most don’t know that Russell Brunson
pioneered the Value Ladder concept as a
whole. Now, with this book, he’s returning with
the Linchpin to fill in the model.
The book you’re about to read could’ve also
been called: Russell Brunson’s Personal
Lessons From Executing His Own Secrets
Trilogy. Get a pen and buckle up, because it
turns out that Russell Brunson actually has
more secrets to share, and you’re holding
them. Get to it.
8 9
A lot of people talk about how ClickFunnels
grew from start-up to over 9 figures in just three
years, and they all point to different reasons
why. Some attribute it to the software, others
because of the community, and others think
it’s because of our books or one of our funnels.
While all of these things are HUGE contributors
to our success, I am fully aware that there was
one small tweak we made to our funnels, about
three weeks after we launched, that instantly
10Xed ClickFunnels almost overnight and was
the key to our rapid growth.
This book will walk you through the model that
we now affectionately call “The Linchpin.” It’s not just a way to build your company and structure
your funnels, it is THE WAY. It’s the model that all
of our coaching clients inside of the Two Comma
Club X Coaching Program follow. It’s the model
that we coach all of my Inner Circle members in
during our mastermind meetings. It is the model
that every one of my companies follow, and if
something doesn’t fit into this Linchpin model,
then we don’t do it. Yes, it’s that important.
This is what the framework of the Linchpin looks
like, and we’ll break it down in this book. Chapter 1
THE LINCHPIN
The Simple, Overlooked Secret In My Funnels That Took Clickfunnels From
Startup To 9 Figures A Year… (In Just 3 Short Years)
The concepts you’ll learn aren’t difficult. In fact,
they are simple. Especially if you already have
an existing business, you’ll notice that it’s a few
small tweaks to how you look at your business
and how you structure your business. After you
make these small changes, you will have the
ability to scale quickly. I know that many of you
already do webinars or challenges. You may
already have a live or virtual event. The goal of
this book isn’t to have you stop doing what’s
working. Instead, it’s to show you how to add
in a few of the other pieces that you’re likely
missing, and that you will need for a scalable
business, and to tie them all together with a
simple linchpin. Following this model will allow
you to grow and scale your company 10X faster.As you will soon see, the actual Linchpin is a
mindset shift on where your self-liquidating
offer is placed, and then where you put just
one simple button, in a very specific place, on
your thank-you pages.
That’s it!
But I don’t want the simplicity of the model to
cause you to overlook its power. I’ve shared this
idea with dozens of my friends over the years,
and almost all of them have discounted it, not
used it, and wondered why we are still growing
so rapidly almost 10 years later! These simple
changes will work to scale any business, but it
will require you to look at it through a different
lens, with an open mind.

The first (and the most) foundational principle you need to understand in order to be successful
with the Linchpin framework is that you need to move where the SLO is located. I taught about
the concept of an SLO in my book, Expert Secrets.
An SLO is a low-priced offer on the thank-you page (often $37-$97) after somebody gives you
their email address and is created to help liquidate your ad costs.
Typically, the SLO is placed on the thank-you page after someone registers for a free challenge,
webinar, summit, or virtual event. We don’t get paid until after the event is over, so the SLO
allows us to put the money we make on the SLO back into ads.
For example, after someone registers for my free Secrets Masterclass, they see my SLO on the
thank-you page that invites them to get a free copy of my DotComSecrets book. The average
person who requests my free book ends up paying $9.97 for shipping, and then we take them
through a funnel where we upsell the audiobook and a course. I usually make over $50 on
average for each person who orders a copy of my book.MOVING THE LOCATION OF THE
SLO (SELF-LIQUIDATING OFFER)You’ve probably seen other SLOs like these:
• After you register for a free challenge: Upgrade to VIP for just $47!
• After you register for a free webinar: Get a special ebook for just $37!
• After you register for a free summit: Get lifetime access to the recordings for just $47!
An SLOSLO is a low-priced
offer on the thank-you
page (often $37-$97)

13 12
Typically, the offer we pitch is a more expensive
offer (usually $297, $997, $1,997, or more)
at the end of a challenge, webinar, summit,
or virtual event. If the SLO covered all of our
ad costs, then what we sell at the end of the
presentation is pure profit!
When we first launched ClickFunnels, this was
the model that we used:
• Step #1: We promoted a free webinar.
• Step #2: People would register for the
webinar, and on the thank-you page
I would sell them a $37 offer to help
cover our ad costs (SLO).
• Step #3: At the end of the webinar,
I  would sell access to ClickFunnels
for 12 months for $997. (After the 12
months was over, we would start billing
them $97 a month for continued access
to our software.) THE TRADITIONAL SLO
We did about a dozen webinars this way,
and I was excited because we started to
make money, but my business partner Todd
Dickerson was upset because he didn’t want
to be in a business where we were only getting
paid when I did a webinar. He came from the
software world, and he wanted to build up a
company with residual, recurring income.
During a late-night discussion after one of our
webinars, Todd had an idea...What if, instead of putting
a $37 SLO on the thank-you
page…what if we put a free 14-
day trial on the thank-you page
instead and encouraged people
to create a free trial BEFORE
the webinar started…and our
new goal was to see HOW MANY
TRIALS we could give away
during the signup process.
If we did that, and our goal
was trials, then we could start
to look at the $997 offer as
the SLO! Every penny we make
from the $997 offer, we dump
back into ads to get more
people to register for the
webinar and create free trials!
—Todd Dickerson
14 15
Boom…that was the idea.
So simple. So Powerful.
And so we tried it. The next webinar, I got rid of the existing SLO and added in a free 14-day
ClickFunnels trial on the Thank-You page. This simple button, and a shift in our mindset, was the
key to our success. The button became the linchpin that tied this all together!
I then filmed a quick video that said:
“Thank you for registering for the webinar! During the live training, I’m going to show you how
to use a new tool called ClickFunnels! You will need an account during the class, so I want to
give you a free 14-day trial. That way you can play with it now and have it for the webinar! After
the webinar, if you decide you don’t want it, you can cancel your account, but you’ll need it for
the class, so go and get your free account now!”
We had no idea that Todd’s weird idea—moving the SLO and adding this one little button—would
be the key to us scaling ClickFunnels from a new start-up into a $100 million/year company in
just three short years!
(Thanks Todd!!!)
…THAT WAS THE IDEA.
SO SIMPLE.
SO POWERFUL.

LOOKED LIKE IN THE ORDER THEY
WENT THROUGH IT.
1. Webinar Registration Page: They registered for the webinar.
2. Webinar Thank-You Page: After registering, some clicked the button and got a
free 2-week trial of ClickFunnels while they waited for the webinar to start.
3. Webinar Offer: They attended the webinar and some signed up for the $997 Offer.
4. Trialers And Yearly Buyers Continue On Continuity:
·Trialers were put into our continuity and some continued at $97/month after
their free 14-day trial ended.
·Those who bought a year’s access were put into our continuity and some
continued at $97/month after their bulk 12-month membership ended.
19 18
We ran this new model hard for the next 12 months. I was doing 2–3 webinars a week,
and we were re-investing all of the money we made from the sales during the webinar
(our new $997 SLO) back into ads for the next webinar.
After 12 months, we sat back and calculated how this Linchpin had affected our bot -
tom line, and the results were amazing.
Over that 12-month period:
• 2,500+ members bought our offer at $997!
·In just one year, we made almost $2,500,000 in sales!
Now, that by itself is pretty amazing, but remember that we didn’t keep that
$2,500,000…we put it back into ads to keep getting people to register for the webinar.
The real magic came when we realized this:
•  After the trials ended, we had 7,500+ members stay on at $97/month.
·That produced almost $750,000/month revenue.
·That meant we had almost $9,000,000 in projected ARR (annual recurring
revenue) from the trialers’ monthly subscriptions!
($750,000 x 12 months = $9,000,000)
That was $9 million (more than 3.6 times MORE money than we made from the
$997 offer) that we would have lost had we not done the Linchpin model!
Not to mention the 2,500 people who did buy the yearly account…a huge percentage
of them continued into monthly recurring when their 12-month account was over!

THE VALUE LADDER
(WITH RULES)
If you’ve read my first book, DotCom Secrets, then you know all about a concept I call the Value
Ladder! The basic principle is that when you increase the value of something you offer, you can
also increase the price. In most businesses, you bring someone in on a lower level of your Value
Ladder with an offer (like a free book or report) where they get some value. If they get value from
that interaction, then they will naturally want more, and they’ll start to ascend up your Value
Ladder, buying other products and services.
The Value LadderValue Ladder is an organized way to
move your customers through your offers.
As customers ascend your Value Ladder,
you’ll provide them more value, so your
offers will increase in price.
In the past, as I’ve taught this concept, there
are two things that often come up. First, many
people think that they have to create ALL of
their products or services in their Value Ladder
before they can start (which isn’t true), or
they have so much fun creating products and
services that soon they have hundreds of offers
and levels, and their Value Ladder becomes a
value maze.
Both of these keep some people from
success. In fact, in my higher level Inner Circle Coaching Program, I typically spend a lot of
time unwinding what people have created. I
tell them that they have to “kill some of their
babies” (in other words, kill some of their
favorite offers) to be successful, and then we
simplify their Value Ladder.
After I first showed the Linchpin framework, I
realized it had the power to fix our customers’
value mazes! In fact, Steve J. Larsen said:
It doesn’t allow you to create a bunch of offers that will confuse your customers. Instead, it puts
rules and restrictions on your Value Ladder to make it flawless—the perfect model—and it shows
you what you need to create and in what order!
I’ll show you later how to put your offers into the Linchpin framework and how to ensure your
Value Ladder doesn’t become a value maze!The Linchpin is basically the
Value Ladder with rules.”
—Steve J. Larsen
24 25
In the next few chapters of this book, I am
going to break down each step, or phase, in
the Linchpin framework.
The Linchpin framework helps you structure
the offers in your Value Ladder for maximum
profit and scalability. In other words, it’s
basically your Value Ladder with rules.The numbers on the Linchpin framework
below represent the order in which you will
create the parts of the framework. As you will
learn in the next chapter, the main goal of the
Linchpin is to build up your continuity revenue.
Everything else is an appendage to building
your continuity income.
This is the path that we’ll cover during the rest
of the book.THE LINCHPIN FRAMEWORK
STAGE 1: THE MIFGE (Steps 1–3)
1. Create Your Continuity Or Subscription Program
You’ll create a continuity program to get paid on a recurring basis.
2. Create Your MIFGE (Most Incredible Free Gift Ever)
You’ll create an irresistible offer that includes a free trial of your continuity.
3. Launch Your MIFGE To The World You’ll use the Attractive Character Flywheel
to sell your MIFGE.
STAGE 2: DRAMATIC DEMONSTRATION #1 (Steps 4–6)
4. Create Your Bulk Continuity + Offer
You’ll create an offer that includes free Bulk Continuity (usually 6 or 12 months).
5. Create Your Dramatic Demonstration #1
You’ll create a challenge or webinar to sell your Bulk Continuity + Offer (plus you’ll
put your MIFGE on the thank-you page of your challenge or webinar to get more
members).
6. Launch Your Dramatic Demonstration #1 To The World
You’ll use the Attractive Character Flywheel to fill your Dramatic Demonstration #1.
STAGE 3: DRAMATIC DEMONSTRATION #2 (Steps 7–9)
7. Create Your High-Ticket Offer
You’ll create a High-Ticket Offer (that includes Bulk Continuity + more).
8. Create Your Dramatic Demonstration #2
You’ll create a virtual or live event to sell your High-Ticket Offer.
9. Launch Your Dramatic Demonstration #2 To The World
You’ll use the Attractive Character Flywheel to fill your Dramatic Demonstration #2.

You might say to yourself, “Isn’t this out of
order? Why do the numbers go backward?”
Just as you can’t drive traffic to a sales page
you haven’t created yet, there’s a certain order
to follow to build out your Linchpin framework.
You do not need to build out the entire Linchpin
framework before launching it. In fact, we
recommend you build it in stages and then
launch each stage in the order below. Even if
all you do is finish Stage 1, you can still have
a successful business. Each stage builds on
the next, so the more stages you complete, the
more successful your business will be.
We’ll dive deeper into each part of the
Linchpin framework in this book, but for
now, just remember that the Linchpin…
…is the best way to scale your business
because your SLO becomes what
everyone else uses for their main source
of business revenue.
…keeps you and your team focused on
growing your continuity.
…builds your continuity which is the
only actual tangible, sellable asset in
your business long-term.
I’m not in the author business.
I’m not in the event business.
I’m in the continuity business.
Everything else is an appendage
that gets more people into the
continuity and gets them to stick
longer and become raving fans.
That’s the only goal at the end of
the day. —Russell Brunson

Chapter 2
CONTINUITY
Without CONTINUITY You Don’t Have A Business
STEP 1: Create Your Continuity Or Subscription Program
You’ll create a continuity program to get paid on a recurring basis.
The entire premise of the Linchpin model is based on a statement that I heard from one of my
friends and mentors, David Frey. He said:
If you don’t have
continuity…then you
don’t have a business.
—David FreyBased on this statement, most entrepreneurs
that I work with, even the very successful
ones, don’t actually have a real business.
They may sell high-ticket products, run live
events, or sell a lot of one-time products, but
because their business isn’t creating residual,
continuity income, they don’t actually have a
business. They have a promotion.
For over a decade, I was in the same boat. Every
few months we launched a new offer, a new
event, a new promotion, and while oftentimes
we had 7- and 8-figure promotions, when the
marketing ended, so did the cash flow.
It wasn’t until we launched ClickFunnels—and
I started to see the compounding effects of
focus on continuity—that I finally understood what David Frey was saying. Every promotion’s
goal was no longer just to make some quick
money, but instead they were designed and
orchestrated with one goal in mind: How do we
get more people into continuity or membership
by creating this product or doing this event?
My focus went from just making money once
(a promotion) to building long-term residual
income (a business). When I first started
working with Dan Kennedy and Bill Glazer in
their mastermind group, Bill told me something
so powerful about their entire business model.
Although they had dozens of books and
courses, as well as live events and tons of
other ways that they made money, he told me:
We’re in the two-things
business: the business
of ‘getting members’ and
‘keeping members.’
—Bill Glazer
30 31
By putting extreme focus on your continuity and
getting new members into it each day, you have
the ability to give yourself a raise every day!
Do you know how nice it is to wake up every day,
check your Stripe app on your phone, and see
